L1.brief_rationale: The 1789 upheaval that overthrew the French monarchy and reshaped European politics is among the most universally taught events in world history.
The 1914–1918 global conflict centered in Europe, known to every educated person and a fixture of secondary-school history curricula worldwide.
The 1939–1945 war involving all major European powers and resulting in the Holocaust and postwar world order; universally recognized.
The vast political entity dominating the Mediterranean world for centuries is a foundational concept in any general historical education.
The mid-14th-century plague that killed roughly a third of Europe's population is universally known as the defining medieval catastrophe.
The 14th–17th-century cultural and intellectual rebirth originating in Italy is universally recognized and taught in virtually every humanities curriculum.
The most famous European military and political leader of the modern era; his name and conquests are known to any educated person globally.
The Nazi genocide of six million Jews and millions of others during World War II is taught universally and carries profound historical and moral importance.
The ideological and geopolitical standoff between the United States and Soviet Union that defined European and global politics from 1947 to 1991.
The civilization recognized as the cradle of Western democracy, philosophy, and science; universally known through school curricula and popular culture.
The 16th-century religious revolution initiated by Martin Luther that permanently fractured Western Christianity is universally taught in world history.
The 1989 event symbolizing the end of the Cold War and German division is one of the most iconic moments of modern European history.
The medieval series of religious wars between Christian Europe and the Muslim world are universally recognized and widely taught at the secondary level.

L2.brief_rationale: The 1814–1815 diplomatic settlement that redrew European borders after Napoleon requires knowledge of 19th-century European statecraft; standard for history students.
The devastating 1618–1648 conflict that engulfed much of Central Europe and culminated in the Peace of Westphalia; known to students of early-modern European history.
The 1215 charter limiting royal power in England is a foundational text in the history of constitutional government; familiar to students of political or legal history.
The 15th–17th-century period of European maritime expansion and colonization requires student-level familiarity with early-modern European power projection.
The 18th-century intellectual movement championing reason, science, and individual rights that underpins modern Western political thought; standard student vocabulary.
The Prussian statesman who unified Germany through 'blood and iron' in 1871; requires student-level knowledge of 19th-century European nationalism and diplomacy.
The eastern continuation of the Roman Empire lasting until 1453; requires familiarity with medieval European and Near Eastern history beyond the general curriculum.
The 1919 peace settlement ending World War I and imposing punishing terms on Germany; well known to history students for its role in enabling the rise of Nazism.
The prolonged 1337–1453 conflict between England and France featuring Joan of Arc; requires student-level knowledge of late-medieval European dynastic politics.
The hierarchical land-tenure and military-service system organizing medieval European society; standard vocabulary for students of medieval history.
The 1917 overthrow of the Tsar and subsequent Bolshevik seizure of power; requires student-level knowledge of early 20th-century European political radicalism.
The 431–404 BC conflict between Athens and Sparta that reshaped the Greek world; requires familiarity with ancient Greek political and military history.
European colonial expansion and its global consequences require student-level understanding of how European power shaped world history from the 15th century onward.

L3.brief_rationale: The 1648 treaties ending the Thirty Years' War that established the principle of state sovereignty; requires understanding of how it shaped the modern international system.
The informal system of great-power diplomacy maintaining European stability from 1815 to 1914; requires working knowledge of 19th-century diplomatic history beyond student basics.

The transformation of English common lands into private property that drove rural displacement and contributed to industrialization; requires contextual understanding of agrarian and economic history.
The wave of liberal and nationalist uprisings across Europe requires working knowledge of 19th-century political ideology and the tensions between liberalism, nationalism, and conservatism.
Charlemagne's 8th–9th-century Frankish realm that defined early medieval political and ecclesiastical organization in Western Europe; requires knowledge beyond general surveys.
The late-19th-century French political scandal exposing antisemitism in the Third Republic; requires understanding of French politics, nationalism, and the role of public intellectuals.
The 19th-century European diplomatic crisis over the decline of the Ottoman Empire and control of its territories; requires working knowledge of great-power competition.
The German democratic government of 1919–1933 that struggled with hyperinflation, political extremism, and Depression; requires understanding of conditions enabling the Nazi rise to power.
The medieval commercial confederation of Northern European trading cities; requires working knowledge of pre-modern European economic history and urban organization.
The 1478–1834 tribunal enforcing Catholic orthodoxy in Spain through investigation and punishment; requires contextual knowledge of religious persecution, conversos, and Iberian history.
The rapid late-19th-century European partition of the African continent requires working knowledge of imperialism, the Berlin Conference, and European rivalries.
The 1825 Russian officers' uprising against autocracy; requires understanding of early Russian liberalism and the tensions between reform and reaction in 19th-century Europe.

L4.brief_rationale: The late-Roman emperor Diocletian's administrative reorganization of the empire into a tetrarchy and his systematic persecution of Christians require deep knowledge of late antique Roman governance.
The 11th–12th-century struggle between the papacy and Holy Roman Emperor over the right to appoint bishops; requires expert understanding of medieval church-state relations and canon law.
The 20th-century French historiographical movement emphasizing long-term social and economic structures over political events; requires expert knowledge of historiography and methodology.

The false German nationalist narrative that the army was undefeated in World War I but betrayed by civilians and Jews; requires deep understanding of Weimar political culture and the origins of Nazism.
The medieval political theology of the legitimate transfer of imperial authority from Rome to subsequent rulers; requires expert knowledge of medieval political thought and the Holy Roman Empire.

The precise sequence of diplomatic ultimatums, mobilization orders, and alliance commitments that triggered World War I in five weeks; requires deep familiarity with the historiography of the war's origins.
The late-Roman Republic land-reform programs of Tiberius and Gaius Gracchus and their violent suppression require expert knowledge of Roman agrarian politics and the crisis of the Republic.
The post-Jacobin conservative turn of the French Revolution following Robespierre's execution in 1794; requires deep knowledge of revolutionary factionalism and periodization debates.

L4.concept: Querelle des Anciens et des Modernes
L4.wikipedia_article: Quarrel of the Ancients and the Moderns
L4.brief_rationale: The late-17th-century French intellectual dispute over whether modern culture surpassed classical antiquity; requires expert knowledge of early modern European intellectual history and the formation of aesthetic theory.
The less-studied but decisive theater of World War I stretching from the Baltic to the Black Sea; requires expert understanding of the war's full strategic picture beyond the Western Front narrative.
The secret 1916 Anglo-French agreement partitioning the Middle East requires expert knowledge of wartime European imperial diplomacy and its long-term consequences for the region.

Henri Pirenne's argument that Islamic expansion, not Germanic invasions, ended ancient Mediterranean civilization and created the Middle Ages; requires expert engagement with historiographic debates on periodization.
